title: People commit 4% less crime on days when high pollen triggers allergies
text:
High pollen seasons may mean low crime, a recent study suggests.

In 16 cities, there is an average of four percent less crime on days when pollen is high, according to a University of Pennsylvania and Wayne State University study published last year.

This year, pollen counts were unusually high and particularly severe in places like the state of Georgia, the city of Chicago, as well as New York City - and experts say that each year will only continue to get worse as the globe warms.

And that's been bad news for allergy sufferers - including criminals - and good news for rates of murder, rape and burglary and assault.

Overall crime was down by 6.7 percent in New York City in April 2019, compared to the previous year - a statistic reported just as allergies were reaching their peak.

Pollen blanketed much of the US in greater quantities for more days than usual in 2019 - and research suggests that it helped drive down the crime rate in 16 cities (file)

If you suffer allergies, you're all too familiar with the symptoms that can lay you flat.

Unbearable sinus pressure, suffocating congestion, eyes that won't stop watering, a running nose to match, swelling, itching, incessant coughing - it's an exhausting combination of symptoms suffered by some 20 million people in the US.

And they keep sufferers home from work an average of 3.6 days a year and distract them from 2.3 hours of tasks a day when they do go to work.

Criminals, it seems, are no exception.

In their 2018 study, published in the Journal of Health Economics, the UPenn and Wayne State researchers looked at data on both crime and pollen counts in 16 cities.

They found that as pollen rose, crime fell, across the board.

Violent crimes like murder, rape, robbery and aggravated assault, were most hindered by allergies, it seemed.

Rates fell by four percent on average on the highest pollen days, the study authors reported.

And the influence of allergies was felt most by New Yorkers, who committed about seven percent fewer violent crimes on days in the highest percentile for pollen.

Interestingly, the study found that allergy season did not have any noticeable effect on property crimes like vandalism and burglary.

But they did see declines in 'residential crime,' like domestic violence.

Intuitively, it might seem like potential offenders simply don't commit violent crimes because they're at home with less opportunity to do so, but the authors argue that the decline in domestic violence suggest otherwise.

It suggested to the study authors that 'the primary way in which these allergies affect people may be through the manifestation of the physical symptoms of illness which we argue changes the costs and benefits of offending as well as of victim precaution.'

They argued that this underscores the 'extent to which violence is responsive to situational factors.'

In other words, it's not just that people aren't out and about where there are crimes to be committed, but that suffering allergies fundamentally changes motivations and the calculus that goes into a crime and underscores 'the extent to which violence is responsive to situational factors.'

Namely: 'malaise driven by pollen allergies.'

More broadly, the study authors note that this is evidence of how 'health shocks,' like allergies, can change human behavior - for better or worse.
description: A 2018 study found that crimes - particularly violent ones -  fall as pollen levels rise, due to the 'malaise' of allergies. Allergy season was historically bad in New York, in 2019 and crime fell 6.7%.
authors: Natalie Rahhal Deputy Health Editor For Dailymail.Com
